clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Surgical Positioning in Arthroscopic Shoulder Stabilization
clinical_study.official_title: The Effects of Surgical Positioning on Arthroscopic Shoulder Stabilization: A Prospective Comparison

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to prospectively determine whether intra-operative factors, complications and post-operative outcomes differ between beach chair and lateral decubitus surgical positioning for patients receiving arthroscopic shoulder stabilization (anterior or posterior) due to shoulder instability.

primary_outcome.description: Participants will be asked by their surgeon at routine follow up visits if they have encountered any episodes of shoulder instability (shoulder dislocations)

secondary_outcome.description: Participant satisfaction will be measured using the American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons score (ASES)
Participant satisfaction will be measured using the Single Assessment Numerical Evaluation survey (SANE)
Participant satisfaction will be measured using the Western Ontario Shoulder Instability (WOSI) index

arm_group.description: Patient positioned in beach chair position during arthroscopic shoulder stabilization
Patient positioned in lateral decubitus position during arthroscopic shoulder stabilization

intervention.description: Patients positioned in beach chair during arthroscopic shoulder stabilization
Patients positioned in lateral decubitus position during arthroscopic shoulder stabilization

study_pop.textblock: Patients who undergo arthroscopic labral repair due to shoulder instability, with or without concomitant debridement.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
-Any patient undergoing arthroscopic labral repair due to shoulder instability, with or without concomitant debridement.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Revision stabilization surgery
- No previous Bankart repairs, labral repairs, capsulorrhaphy, or Latarjet
- Multidirectional shoulder instability
- Concomitant rotator cuff repair, biceps tenodesis/tenotomy, HAGL repair
- Isolated SLAP repair/labral repair in association with mechanism other than -instability (eg: overhead athletes) open procedures for instability
